text: S3 users - does anyone routinely sync their objects to their local machine? I like to use the sync utility and keep a local copy of my market data rather than load market data over the network into memory each time I want to access it. Lately I've found that due to the number of objects I have I have to spend a few minutes syncing. Not a massive issue since market data access is super fast once it's all local, but not sure if there's a better way to approach this.

elements.text: S3 users - does anyone routinely sync their objects to their local machine? I like to use the sync utility and keep a local copy of my market data rather than load market data over the network into memory each time I want to access it. Lately I've found that due to the number of objects I have I have to spend a few minutes syncing. Not a massive issue since market data access is super fast once it's all local, but not sure if there's a better way to approach this.

text: I do keep local copies for faster processing but I don’t sync in that way. For example, I keep all of my historic Betfair data in S3 but there’s a lot of market types I don’t care about so I only have local copies of the ones of interest

elements.text: I do keep local copies for faster processing but I don’t sync in that way. For example, I keep all of my historic Betfair data in S3 but there’s a lot of market types I don’t care about so I only have local copies of the ones of interest

text: I have found having a database table containing meta data for S3 objects to be useful so you can use that for searching rather than making S3 API requests

elements.text: I have found having a database table containing meta data for S3 objects to be useful so you can use that for searching rather than making S3 API requests

text: Also, if you keep the structure they use for historical data you can just sync subdirectories of it, instead of the whole bucket

elements.text: Also, if you keep the structure they use for historical data you can just sync subdirectories of it, instead of the whole bucket

text: (or any YYYY/MM/DD kind of structure, for what is worth)

elements.text: (or any YYYY/MM/DD kind of structure, for what is worth)

text: This is probably a dumb question, but here it goes anyway: can you get matched with your own orders? does betfair allow that? If not, how can it be avoided?

elements.text: This is probably a dumb question, but here it goes anyway: can you get matched with your own orders? does betfair allow that? If not, how can it be avoided?

text: Yes you can

elements.text: Yes you can

text: It is very much frowned upon

elements.text: It is very much frowned upon

text: Really? You can match your own orders and that will count towards total market traded volume?

text: Wow. So you could load up a lot of ladder volume at current price and several ticks below, then shove in a massive back order to match mostly your own money to make it appear as a large back to manipulate the price? Just outlining a probably naive thought process here

text: It will depend on the context I am sure. If you are manipulating the market in the way <@UUE6E1LA1> describes or you are using it for premium charge avoidance as I have been party to then they will shut it down quickly.
